title: Windrush immigrant ‘died from stress when he couldn’t prove he was British’
text:
Dexter Bristol, 58, was worried that he couldn’t visit a doctor due to his immigration status (Picture: PA)

A Windrush immigrant who had been in the UK for 50 years, died ‘from the stress of losing his job, when he couldn’t prove he was British’, an inquest has heard.

Dexter Bristol, 58, had battled to prove his right to remain in the country and as his health deteriorated, worried that he couldn’t see a doctor due to his immigration status.

He worked at Great Ormond Street Hospital and suffered a cardiac arrest outside Mullen Towers in Mount Pleasant, London, on March 28, 2018.

Mr Bristol arrived in the UK from Grenada when he was eight years old, with only his name and date of birth added to his mother’s passport.

According to a consultant cardiologist, there was ‘reasonable case’ to believe that Mr Bristol’s heart attack was down to the stress he was under at ‘finding out that he had to prove his right to remain in the UK’.

Professor Jaswinder Singh Gill said: ‘There is a reasonable case to be made that stress contributed to the arrhythmia that lead to his death.

‘The circumstances seem to indicate that he was under a high level of stress having found out that he could have to prove his right to remain in the UK and would lose his income.

Mr Bristol arrived in the UK from Grenada when he was eight years old (Picture: PA Archive/PA Images)

‘That may have contributed to the fact that he had an arrythmia.’

Mr Bristol was also upset after finding out that his mum was not his biological mother, according to the job agency Maximus.

However, a pathologist disagreed and told the hearing that Mr Bristol suffered from a heart condition and stress played no part in his death.

Pathologist Alan Bates concluded that the stress of having to prove his right to reside in the UK was not a factor – nor was stress of any kind.

The coffin of Dexter Bristol during his funeral service at Honor Oak Crematorium in London (Picture: PA)

He told St Pancras Coroners’ Court: ‘I think there is no reason to suppose that chronic anxiety should be considered a contributing factor.’

A postmortem examination revealed that Mr Bristol was living with a long-term heart condition called aortic stenosis – a weakness that left him vulnerable to death if his heart beat irregularly, known as arrhythmia.

A statement from his mother, Sentina Bristol, revealed how worries about his right to reside in the UK came during a meeting with his employer and how she blamed his death on his fight for proof.

Mother Sentina Bristol says her son wouldn’t have died if it hadn’t been for the stress over his immigration status (Picture: PA)

She said: ‘In early 2017 he contacted me and asked me where his passport was. He told me that when he showed this old passport to his employer they told him that if the Home Office saw it they would deport him.

‘I contacted Jackelin McKenzie [a solicitor]. Dexter and I went to see Miss McKenzie who told him he would have to apply for a Grenadian passport and supply records of early life in Britain to get a British passport.

‘He got his Granadan passport. Throughout this period of his life he was stressed and depressed.

She added: ‘I’m hurt and upset that he had to prove his right to live in the UK, I don’t think he would have died aged only 58 if he had not gone through the year of stress and worry.’

description: Dexter Bristol, 58, had 'battled to prove his right to remain in the country as his health deteriorated', an inquest heard.
